DT Article
TI Revision of the funnel-web spider genus Novalena (Araneae: Agelenidae).
AU Maya-Morales, Julieta (dianobi@yahoo.com) 
   Luisa Jimenez, Maria
SO Zootaxa
VL 4262
IS 1
PS 1-88
PD May 5 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The Western Hemisphere genus Novalena Chamberlin & Ivie 1942 (Araneae:
   Agelenidae) is revised. The genus now includes a total of 53 species, of
   which 40 are new species from USA, Mexico, Guatemala, and Costa Rica: N.
   ajusco sp. nov. (a), N. alamo sp. nov. (a), N. alvarezi sp. nov. (a), N.
   atzimbo sp. nov. (a), N. bosencheve sp. nov. (a), N. chamberlini sp.
   nov. (a a), N. cieneguilla sp. nov. (a), N. cintalapa sp. nov. (a a), N.
   clara sp. nov. (a a), N. comaltepecsp. nov. (a), N. creel sp. nov. (a
   a), N. dentata sp. nov. (a a), N. divisadero sp. nov. (a), N. durango
   sp. nov. (a), N. franckei sp. nov. (a a), N. garnica sp. nov. (a a), N.
   gibarrai sp. nov. (a a), N. irazu sp. nov. (a), N. iviei sp. nov. (a),
   N. ixtlan sp. nov. (a), N. jiquilpan sp. nov. (a), N. leonensis sp. nov.
   (a a), N. mexiquensis sp. nov. (a a), N. oaxacasp. nov. (a a), N.
   paricutin sp. nov. (a), N. perote sp. nov. (a a), N. plata sp. nov. (a),
   N. poncei sp. nov. (a a), N. popoca sp. nov. (a), N. prieta sp. nov.
   (a), N. puebla sp. nov. (a a), N. punta sp. nov. (a a), N. rothi sp.
   nov. (a a), N. saltoensis sp. nov. (a), N. sinaloa sp. nov. (a), N.
   tacana sp. nov. (a a), N. triunfo sp. nov. (a), N. valdezi sp. nov. (a
   a), N. victoria sp. nov. (a), and N. volcanes sp. nov. (a). Nine are
   previously described species: N. annamae (Gertsch & Davis 1940), N.
   attenuata (F.O. Pickard-Cambridge 1902), N. bipartita (Kraus 1955), N.
   calavera Chamberlin & Ivie 1942, N. costata (F.O. Pickard-Cambridge
   1902), N. laticava (Kraus 1955), N. orizaba (Banks 1898), N. shlomitae(
   Garcia-Villafuerte 2009), and N. simplex (F.O. Pickard-Cambridge 1902).
   Four new synonyms are proposed: N. pina Chamberlin & Ivie 1942 = N.
   intermedia (Chamberlin & Gertsch 1930); N. idahoana (Gertsch 1934) and
   N. wawona Chamberlin & Ivie 1942 = N. lutzi (Gertsch 1933); N. tolucana
   (Gertsch & Davis 1940) = N. approximata (Gertsch & Ivie 1936). One
   species is transferred from Melpomene back to Novalena: N. bipunctata
   Roth 1967 stat. rev. One species is transferred to Hoffmannilena
   Maya-Morales & Jimnez 2016: H. nova (O. Pickard-Cambridge 1896) comb.
   nov.
C1 Maya-Morales, Julieta; Ctr Invest Biol Noroeste CIBNOR, Lab Aracnol &
   Entomol, La Paz, Baja California, 23096, Mexico, Mexico.
EM dianobi@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Novalena mexiquensis (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 58].

   Hoffmannilena, p. 82]. 
   Novalena oaxaca (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 60]. 
   Novalena paricutin (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 61]. 
   Novalena perote (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 63]. 
   Novalena plata (Araneae): [Sp nov, Colorado, P. 64]. 
   Novalena poncei (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 65]. 
   Novalena popoca (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 66]. 
   Novalena prieta (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 67]. 
   Novalena puebla (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 68]. 
   Novalena punta (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 70]. 
   Novalena rothi (Araneae): [Sp nov, Arizona, P. 72]. 
   Novalena saltoensis (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 73]. 
   Novalena sinaloa (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 74]. 
   Novalena tacana (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 75]. 
   Novalena triunfo (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 78].

DT Article
TI A new species of Carcinonemertes, Carcinonemertes conanobrieni sp nov
   (Nemertea: Carcinonemertidae), an egg predator of the Caribbean spiny
   lobster, Panulirus argus.
AU Simpson, Lunden Alice
   Ambrosio, Louis John
   Baeza, J. Antonio (jbaezam@clemson.edu) 
SO PLoS ONE
VL 12
IS 5
PS e0177021
PD May 5 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB A new species of nemertean worm belonging to the genus Carcinonemertes
   is described from egg masses of the Caribbean spiny lobster Panulirus
   argus from the Florida Keys, Florida, USA. This is the first species of
   Carcinonemertes reported to infect P. argus or any other lobster species
   in the greater Caribbean and western Atlantic Ocean. Carcinonemertes
   conanobrieni sp. nov. varies in body color from a translucent white to a
   pale orange, with males ranging in total body length from 2.35 to 12.71
   mm and females ranging from 0.292 to 16.73 mm. Among the traits that
   separate this new species from previously described species in the genus
   Carcinonemertes are a relatively wide stylet basis, minimal sexual size
   dimorphism, and a unique mucus sheath decorated with external hooks.
   Also, juvenile worms were found to encyst themselves next to lobster
   embryos and female worms lay both long strings of eggs wound throughout
   the lobster's setae as well as spherical cases that are attached to
   lobster embryos. The stylet length and stylet basis remain unchanged
   throughout ontogeny for both male and female worms. Maximum likelihood
   and Bayesian inference phylogenetic analyses separated this newly
   described species from all other species of Carcinonemertes with
   available COI sequences. Carcinonemertes spp. are voracious egg
   predators and have been tied to the collapse of various crustacean
   fisheries. The formal description of this new species represents the
   first step to understand putative impacts of this worm on the population
   health of one of the most lucrative yet already depressed crustacean
   fisheries.
C1 Baeza, J. Antonio; Clemson Univ, Dept Biol Sci, Clemson, SC, 29634, USA,
   USA.
EM jbaezam@clemson.edu
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1932-6203
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Associations; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Carcinonemertes conanobrieni [Associations / Panulirus argus (Crustacea)
   / New associate species] [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Florida / New species;
   crustacean associate]. 
   Panulirus argus [Associations / Carcinonemertes conanobrieni
   (Nemertinea) / New associate species] [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Florida /
   New associated nemertine species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Palinura, Nemertinea
OR Panulirus argus (Palinura). 
   Carcinonemertes - Coe 1902 (Nemertinea): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 14]. 
   Carcinonemertes conanobrieni (Nemertinea): [Sp nov, USA, Florida
   (marine), Associated with Panulirus argus (Crustacea), p. 5].

DT Article
TI Xibalbanus cozumelensis, a new species of Remipedia (Crustacea) from
   Cozumel, Mexico, and a molecular phylogeny of Xibalbanus on the Yucatan
   Peninsula.
AU Olesen, Jorgen (jolesen@snm.ku.dk) 
   Meland, Kenneth
   Glenner, Henrik
   Van Hengstum, Peter J.
   Iliffe, Thomas M.
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 316
PS 1-27
PD May 5 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species belonging to the crustacean class Remipedia is described
   from an anchialine cave system on the island of Cozumel (Mexico), and is
   illustrated and compared morphologically and molecularly (CO1 and 16S)
   with closely related taxa. Xibalbanus cozumelensis sp. nov., the first
   remipede described from Cozumel, is morphologically similar to
   Xibalbanus tulumensis (Yager, 1987) from the Yucatan Peninsula, but the
   two species are genetically separate from each other (about 10% in CO1).
   A phylogenetic (Bayesian) analysis of Yucatan remipede populations based
   on CO1 and 16S placed them in a monophyletic Xibalbanus (in Xibalbanidae
   fam. nov.), with X. cozumelensis as most closely related to X.
   tulumensis. The Yucatan Peninsula and Cozumel have been separate since
   approx. early Cenozoic (a 65 Ma), which suggests allopatric speciation
   for X. cozumelensis sp. nov. and X. tulumensis. However, the
   comparatively low genetic divergence between the two species may
   indicate that there has been gene flow between 'mainland' Yucatan and
   Cozumel long after the geological separation of the two landmasses,
   e.g., in cave systems under the sea bed, either continuously or
   sporadically, for example during the Last Glacial Maximum when the sea
   level was about 120 m lower than today.
C1 Olesen, Jorgen; Univ Copenhagen, Nat Hist Museum Denmark, Copenhagen,
   Denmark, Denmark.
EM jolesen@snm.ku.dk

OI Olesen, Jorgen/0000-0001-9582-7083; Illife, Thomas/0000-0002-4342-5960;
   van Hengstum, Pete/0000-0002-1125-2858
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 2118-9773

   Taxonomic position; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region;
   North America

   systematics] [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / ] [Mexico / Yucatan
   Peninsula / ]. 
   Xibalbanus cozumelensis [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI A new genus of proteocephalid tapeworm (Cestoda) from the marbled swamp
   eel Synbranchus marmoratus Bloch (Synbranchiformes: Synbranchidae) in
   the River Parana basin, Argentina.
AU Arredondo, Nathalia J. (arredondonj@bg.fcen.uba.ar) 
   Alves, Philippe Vieira
   Gil de Pertierra, Alicia A.
SO Folia Parasitologica (Ceske Budejovice)
VL 64
PS 015
PD May 5 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Synbranchiella gen. n. is proposed to accommodate Synbranchiella mabelae
   sp. n. (Proteocephalidae: Monticelliinae) from the intestine of the
   marbled swamp eel Synbranchus marmoratus Bloch, in the River Colastine,
   a tributary of the middle River Parana in Argentina. The new genus is
   placed in the Monticelliinae because of the cortical position of the
   genital organs. It differs from all known monticelliine genera by the
   following combination of characters: (i) scolex robust, with a conical
   apex, without metascolex; (ii) biloculate suckers with a conspicuous
   septum separating unequally-sized loculi and a robust non-adherent area,
   lacking free posterior margin; (iii) vitelline follicles in two narrow
   lateral bands, extended throughout the nearly entire proglottid length;
   (iv) vagina always anterior to the cirrus-sac, with an inconspicuous
   vaginal sphincter; (v) a genital pore pre-equatorial. Scanning electron
   microscopy revealed three types of microtriches on the tegument surface:
   acicular and capiliform filitriches and gladiate spinitriches. A
   phylogenetic analysis of the large subunit nuclear ribosomal RNA gene
   (lsrDNA, D1-D3 domains) confirms that S. mabelae represents an
   independent lineage within a large clade comprised mainly from
   Neotropical taxa parasitising catfishes. This is the second
   proteocephalidean cestode described from a Neotropical synbranchiform
   fish host.
C1 Arredondo, Nathalia J.; Univ Buenos Aires, Fac Ciencias Exactas & Nat,
   Ciudad Univ,Pabellon 2,Piso 4,Lab 52,C1428EHA, Buenos Aires, DF,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM arredondonj@bg.fcen.uba.ar
RI Alves, Philippe Vieira/G-6904-2018
OI Alves, Philippe Vieira/0000-0002-3836-5676

SN 0015-5683

   South America

   parasite species] [Argentina /  / New species from piscean host]. 
   Synbranchus marmoratus [Cestode parasites / Synbranchiella mabelae / New
   parasite species] [Argentina /  / New platyhelminth parasite species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates

TI [Hellenika pantoia, XLVI. Messa Mani (Peloponnese, Greece) - 35 Years
   later.]
FT Hellenika pantoia, XLVI. Die Messa Mani (Peloponnes, Griechenland) - 35
   Jahre spater.
AU Reischuetz, Alexander
   Steiner-Reischuetz, Nicole
   Reischuetz, Peter L.
SO Nachrichtenblatt der Ersten Vorarlberger Malakologischen Gesellschaft
VL 24
PS 63-64
PD May 4 2017
PY 2017
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB 35 years after the first finding of Zonites algirus (LINNE 1758) on the
   peninsula Mani (Peloponissos, Greece) the distribution of that species
   was controlled. A severe decline was noticed. In addition a new
   subspecies of Speleodentorcula beroni GITTENBERGER 1985 could be found.

DT Article
TI Reappraisal of Synagrops Guenther, 1887 with rehabilitation and revision
   of Parascombrops Alcock, 1889 including description of seven new species
   and two new genera (Perciformes: Acropomatidae).
AU Schwarzhans, Werner W. (wwschwarz@aol.com) 
   Prokofiev, Artem M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4260
IS 1
PS 1-74
PD May 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB An ongoing review of the fishes of the basal percoid family
   Acropomatidae has revealed that the genus Synagrops Gunther, 1887 as it
   is currently understood is not a natural group. Species with a serrated
   pelvic-fin spine are here placed in the resurrected genus Parascombrops
   Alcock, 1889 (type-species: Parascombrops pellucidus Alcock, 1889), and
   the new, monospecific genus Caraibops n. gen. (type-species: Synagrops
   trispinosus Mochizuki & Sano, 1984). Parascombrops is unique amongst
   Acropomatidae in the combination of the presence of vacant 8th
   interneural space, a predorsal formula /0+0/0+2/ and an epaxialis
   attachment type 1. Caraibops n. gen. shares none of these characters and
   further differs from Parascombrops by an anal-fin formula of III + 9 (vs
   II + 7 or III + 6), and the absence of denticles on the ectopterygoid.
   Parascombrops is revised and now contains a total of 13 species,
   including 7 new: P. analis (Katayama, 1957), P. argyreus (Gilbert &
   Cramer, 1897), P. glossodon n. sp., P. madagascariensis n. sp., P.
   mochizukii n. sp., P. nakayamai n. sp., P. ohei n. sp., P. parvidens n.
   sp., P. pellucidus Alcock, 1889, P. philippinensis (Gunther, 1880), P.
   serratospinosus (Smith & Radcliffe, 1912), P. spinosus (Schultz, 1940)
   and P. yamanouei n. sp. Synagrops adeni Kotthaus, 1970 and S. malayanus
   Weber, 1913 are treated as synonyms of P. pellucidus and P.
   philippinensis, respectively. Lectotypes are designated for P.
   philippinensis and S. malayanus. The main characters used to distinguish
   between the species of Parascombrops are: serration of other fin spines,
   number of gill rakers and pseudobranchial filaments, head profile,
   presence or absence of ridges on the preopercle, shape of 1st anal-fin
   pterygiophore, dentition on vomer, palatines and ectopterygoids, orbit
   diameter, pectoral-fin length, maximal body depth and otolith
   morphology. The genus Synagrops is here confined to two species, S.
   japonicus (Doderlein, 1883) and S. bellus (Goode & Bean, 1896),
   characterized by the apomorphic character of an otic capsule with a
   posteriorly open myodome, a basioccipital fossa and a very specialized
   otolith morphology. Synagrops is also characterized by the absence of
   pelvic-fin spine serrations. Two other species without a serrated
   pelvic- fin spine, originally described in Synagrops, are removed from
   this genus. Synagrops microlepis Norman, 1935 is separated into the
   monotypic Kaperangus n. gen., the only genus in the family with two
   supraneurals (cf. three in all other taxa). The second, Synagrops
   pseudomicrolepis Schultz, 1940 is re-assigned to the genus Verilus. The
   geographic distribution of Parascombrops as currently composed is
   discussed, and is shown to be primarily of West Pacific nature, with few
   species in the Indian Ocean and one in the tropical West-Atlantic (P.
   spinosus). The West Atlantic species Parascombrops spinosus is very
   closely related to P. mochizukii from the tropical northwestern Pacific,
   and the implications of this disjunct distribution are discussed. The
   high degree of speciation now recognized in Parascombrops species of the
   West-Pacific indicates that a diverse ecological adaptation within an
   overall pseudoceanic habitat may have played a major role in speciation,
   which would have remained obscured without adequate taxonomic
   resolution. Fossil, otolith-based records are also briefly discussed in
   the context. The extant Parascombrops argyreus and P. ohei are reported
   from the Pliocene of Japan, and Caraibops trispinosus has been recorded
   from the Pliocene of Venezuela.
C1 Schwarzhans, Werner W.; Ahrensburger Weg 103, Hamburg, D-22359, Germany,
   Germany.
EM wwschwarz@aol.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key;
   Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Parascombrops glossodon [Bay of Bengal / Myanmar / New species] [North
   Pacific / Philippines / ] [ / Taiwan / ] [South Pacific / Australia,

PT J

DT Article
TI Comparative swimming and station-holding ability of the threatened Rocky
   Mountain Sculpin (Cottus sp.) from four hydrologically distinct rivers.
AU Veillard, Marie F.
   Ruppert, Jonathan L.W.
   Tierney, Keith
   Watkinson, Douglas A.
   Poesch, Mark (poesch@ualberta.ca) 
SO Conservation Physiology
VL 5
PS cox026
PD May 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 2
U2 4
AB Hydrologic alterations, such as dams, culverts or diversions, can
   introduce new selection pressures on freshwater fishes, where they are
   required to adapt to novel environmental conditions. Our study
   investigated how species adapt to natural and altered stream flow, where
   we use the threatened Rocky Mountain Sculpin (Cottus sp.) as a model
   organism. We compared the swimming and station-holding performance of
   Rocky Mountain Sculpin from four different hydrologic regimes in Alberta
   and British Columbia, including the North Milk River, a system that
   experiences increased flows from a largescale diversion. We measured the
   slip (Uslip) and failure (Uburst) velocities over three constant
   acceleration test trials. Uslip was defined as the point at which
   individuals required the addition of bursting or swimming to maintain
   position. Uburst was defined as the point at which individuals were
   unable to hold position in the swimming chamber through swimming,
   bursting or holding techniques without fully or partially resting on the
   electrified back plate. We found individuals from the Flathead River in
   British Columbia (with the highest natural flow) failed at significantly
   higher Uburst velocities than fish from the southern Albertan
   populations. However, there was no relationship between peak hydrologic
   flow from the natal river and Uburst or Uslip. Further, Uburst
   velocities decreased from 51.8 cm s-1 (7.2 BL s-1) to 45.6 cm s-1 (6.3
   BL s-1) by the third consecutive test suggesting the use of anaerobic
   metabolism. Uslip was not different between trials suggesting the use of
   aerobic metabolism in station-holding behaviours (Uslip). Moreover, we
   found no significant differences in individuals from the altered North
   Milk River system. Finally, individual caudal morphological
   characteristics were related to both slip and failure velocities. Our
   study contributes to the conservation of Rocky Mountain Sculpin by
   providing the first documentation of swimming and station-holding
   abilities of this benthic fish.
C1 Poesch, Mark; Univ Alberta, Dept Renewable Resources, 751 Gen Serv Bldg,
   Edmonton, AB, T6G 2H1, Canada, Canada.
EM poesch@ualberta.ca
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation; Zoology;
   Anatomy &Morphology; Physiology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 2051-1434
BD Conservation; Biometrics; General morphology; Whole animal physiology;
   Metabolic rate; Locomotion; Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Lotic water;
   Abiotic factors; Physical factors; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada
DE Cottus [Endangered status / Conservation status / first report;
   comparative study] [Size / Length / ] [Tail / Caudal region / ] [Oxygen
   consumption / Oxygen consumption rate / ] [Swimming / Swimming
   performance / ] [River /  / ] [Water movements / Water flow / ] [Alberta
   / South / ] [British Columbia /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Scorpaeniformes, Cottidae
OR Cottus (Cottidae).

DT Article
TI Twenty-seven new species of the goblin spider genus Neoxyphinus Biraben,
   1953 (Araneae: Oonopidae) from Brazil.
AU Feitosa, Nithomas M. (nithomasmateus@gmail.com) 
   Moss, Daniella F.
   Ruiz, Gustavo R.S.
   Bonaldo, Alexandre B.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4259
IS 1
PS 1-107
PD May 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Twenty-seven new species of the genus Neoxyphinus are described, all
   from Brazil, raising the total number of species of the genus to 48. The
   new species with the respective geographic distribution and known sexes
   are: N. capiranga sp. nov. ([male][female]) from Amazonas, Para, Mato
   Grosso and Rondonia; N. caprichoso sp. nov. ([male][female]) and N.
   garantido sp. nov. ([male][female]) from Amazonas and Para; N. crasto
   sp. nov. ([male][female]) from Bahia and Sergipe; N. murici sp. nov.
   ([male][female]) from Alagoas and Sergipe; N. meurei sp. nov. ([female])
   from Bahia and Mato Grosso; N. belterra sp. nov. ([male][female]) from
   Para and Mato Grosso; N. ornithogoblin sp. nov. ([male][female]), N. sax
   sp. nov. ([male][female]), N. coari sp. nov. ([male][female]), N. tucuma
   sp. nov. ([male][female]), N. ducke sp. nov. ([male]) and N. carigoblin
   sp. nov. ([female]) from Amazonas; N. almerim sp. nov. ([male]), N.
   mutum sp. nov. ([male][female]), N. caxiuana sp. nov. ([male][female]),
   N. cachimbo sp. nov. ([male]) and N. jacareacanga sp. nov. ([female])
   from Para; N. paraty sp. nov. ([male][female]) and N. rio sp. nov.
   ([male][female]) from Rio de Janeiro; N. novalima sp. nov.
   ([male][female]) and N. celluliticus sp. nov. ([male]) from Minas
   Gerais; N. paraiba sp. nov. ([male]) and N. simsinho sp. nov.
   ([male][female]) from Paraaba; N. cantareira sp. nov. ([male]) from Sao
   Paulo; N. cavus sp. nov. ([male]) from Esparito Santo and N. stigmatus
   sp. nov. ([male]) from Bahia. A key for identification of all 48 known
   species of Neoxyphinus is provided and possible monophyletic lineages
   within the genus are discussed.

DT Article
TI The first Late Triassic Chinese triadophlebiomorphan (Insecta:
   Odonatoptera): biogeographic implications.
AU Zheng, Daran (dranzheng@gmail.com) 
   Nel, Andre
   Wang, He
   Wang, Bo
   Jarzembowski, Edmund A.
   Chang, Su-Chin
   Zhang, Haichun
SO Scientific Reports
VL 7
PS 1476
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The clade Triadophlebiomorpha represents a morphological 'link' between
   the Paleozoic griffenflies (Meganisoptera) and the modern taxa.
   Nevertheless they are relatively poorly known in the body structures and
   paleobiogeography. The Triassic dragonfly is extremely rare in China
   with only one previously recorded. A new family, Sinotriadophlebiidae
   Zheng, Nel et Zhang fam. nov., for the genus and species
   Sinotriadophlebia lini Zheng, Nel et Zhang gen. et sp. nov., is
   described from the Upper Triassic Baijiantan Formation of Xinjiang,
   northwestern China. It is the second Chinese Triassic odonatopteran and
   the second largest Mesozoic representative of this superorder in China.
   The discovery provides new information for the clade Triadophlebiomorpha
   during the Late Triassic and expands its distribution and diversity in
   Asia. The find reflects a close relationship between the two Triassic
   entomofaunas from Kyrgyzstan and the Junggar Basin, and provides a
   Carnian age constraint on the lowermost part of the Baijiantan
   Formation.
C1 Zheng, Daran; Chinese Acad Sci, Nanjing Inst Geol & Palaeontol, 39 East
   Beijing Rd, Nanjing, Jiangsu, 210008, China, China.
EM dranzheng@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 2045-2322
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Sinotriadophlebia [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
   Sinotriadophlebia lini [Xinjiang Uygur /  / new species] [Triassic /  /
   ]. 
   Sinotriadophlebiidae [Triassic /  / New family]. 
   Triadophlebiomorpha [Zoogeography / Palaeobiogeography / New record;
   systematics] [China /  / ] [Triassic / Late Triassic / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Odonata
OR Sinotriadophlebia - Zheng, Nel & Zhang 2017 (Insecta): [Gen nov, Of new
   family Sinotriadophlebiidae, Type species Sinotriadophlebia lini Zheng,
   Nel & Zhang 2017, p. 2, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Sinotriadophlebia lini - Zheng, Nel & Zhang 2017 (Insecta): [Sp nov,
   Xinjiang Uygur, Triassic, P. 2; Fossil]. 
   Sinotriadophlebiidae - Zheng, Nel & Zhang 2017 (Insecta): [Fam nov, Of
   clade Triadophlebiida, Type genus Sinotriadophlebia Zheng, Nel & Zhang
   2017, p. 2, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Triadophlebiomorpha (Odonata): [Fossil; New record].

DT Article
TI New Protoribates (Acari, Oribatida, Haplozetidae) from Vietnam.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Stary, Josef
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 6
PS 501-524
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Three new species of oribatid mites of the genus Protoribates
   (Oribatida, Haplozetidae) are described based on adult specimens from
   the Tam Dao National Park of Northern Vietnam. Protoribates chistyakovi
   sp. nov. differs from P. sangumburiensis (Choi, 1996) by being larger,
   the localization of lamellar setae, and morphology of rostrum and
   interlamellar setae. Protoribates shaldybinae sp. nov. differs from P.
   dentatus (Berlese, 1883) by its distinctly foveolate body surface,
   morphology of pedotecta II and leg tarsi I and II, and much longer
   adanal setae ad2. Protoribates shvanderovi sp. nov. differs from P.
   gracilis (Aoki, 1982) by its larger body size, localization of lamellar
   setae, and the relative lengths of lamellar, interlamellar and
   bothridial setae, and longer dorsophragmata. An identification key to
   the Vietnamese species of the genus Protoribates is given.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Tyumen State Univ, Tyumen, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
RI Stary, Josef/G-2721-2014
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Protoribates [Vietnam /  / Key to species]. 
   Protoribates chistyakovi; Protoribates shaldybinae; Protoribates
   shvanderovi [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Protoribates - Berlese 1908 (Acari): [Key to species, Vietnam, P. 522]. 
   Protoribates chistyakovi (Acari): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 502]. 
   Protoribates shaldybinae (Acari): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 509]. 
   Protoribates shvanderovi (Acari): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 516].

DT Article
TI A new species of Rock Gecko genus Cnemaspis (Squamata: Gekkonidae) from
   Western Sarawak, Malaysia.
AU Kurita, Takaki (mofumofu_monticola@hotmail.co.jp) 
   Nishikawa, Kanto
   Matsui, Masafumi
   Hikida, Tsutomu
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 6
PS 525-538
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of Asian rock gecko, genus Cnemaspis, is described from
   Padawan, western Sarawak, Malaysian Borneo. The new species forms a
   clade with C. paripari and C. nigridia of the C. nigridia group in a
   mitochondrial DNA phylogeny and is similar to them morphologically in
   some characters such as caudal scalation. It differs from the other
   Asian Cnemaspis species in its unique combination of snout-vent length
   (up to 62.7 mm), 4-9 precloacal pores in males, keeled subcaudals with
   an enlarged, smooth, median row, presence of ventrolateral caudal
   tubercles, and coloration (head and upper flanks dark-yellow; anterior
   portion of tail black; posterior portion of tail white with black,
   paravertebral blob). Phylogenetic relationships within the C. nigridia
   group and the distributional ranges of species within the group suggest
   allopatric speciation by geographic isolation.
C1 Kurita, Takaki; Chiba Biodivers Ctr, Chuo Ku, 955-2 Aoba Cho, Chiba,
   2608682, Japan, Japan.
EM mofumofu_monticola@hotmail.co.jp
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Biometrics; General
   morphology; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cnemaspis leucura [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
   Cnemaspis nigridia species group [Biometrics / Morphometrics /
   systematics] [General morphology /  / ] [Molecular genetics / mtDNA ND2
   gene sequences / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Asia / Borneo / distribution].

   Sauria, Gekkonidae

   subordinate taxa, Bornean species, p. 535]. 
   Cnemaspis leucura (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 528]. 
   Cnemaspis nigridia species group (Gekkonidae).

DT Article
TI A new species of Tropidophorus Dumeril & Bibron, 1839 (Squamata: Sauria:
   Scincidae) from Sarawak, East Malaysia (Borneo).
AU Pui, Yong Min (pui8783ibec@gmail.com) 
   Karin, Benjamin R.
   Bauer, Aaron M.
   Das, Indraneil
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 6
PS 539-550
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new species of the genus Tropidophorus is described from Putai, upper
   Baleh, Kapit districts, Sarawak, East Malaysia (Borneo). Tropidophorus
   sebi sp. nov. is diagnosable from congeners from Borneo by the
   combination of the following characters: head shields present, dorsal
   and lateral scales smooth; parietal scales in two pairs; supraciliaries
   eight; supraoculars four; supralabials seven; infralabials four;
   postmental undivided; longitudinal scale rows 58; ventrals 53;
   transverse scale rows at midbody 34; subcaudals 98; preanals enlarged,
   single; and subdigital lamellae of Toe IV 19. In addition, we determine
   the phylogenetic position of this species within the Tropidophorus group
   based on mitochondrial markers, and present a key to identification of
   the known Bornean species in the genus.
C1 Pui, Yong Min; Univ Malaysia Sarawak, Inst Biodivers & Environm
   Conservat, Kota Samarahan, Sarawak, 94300, Malaysia, Malaysia.
EM pui8783ibec@gmail.com

DT Article
TI Oxynoemacheilus kentritensis, a new species from the upper Tigris
   drainage in Turkey with remarks on O. frenatus (Teleostei:
   Nemacheilidae).
AU Freyhof, Joerg (j.freyhof@igb-berlin.de) 
   Kaya, Cuneyt
   Turan, Davut
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 6
PS 551-560
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Oxynoemacheilus kentritensis, new species, is described from the Botan
   drainage, a tributary to the upper Tigris. It is distinguished from
   other Oxynoemacheilus species in the Tigris drainage by having a
   complete lateral line, long barbels, flank and back completely covered
   by scales and flank behind dorsal-fin base with large, dark-brown,
   vertically elongated blotches or bars.
C1 Freyhof, Joerg; Leibniz Inst Freshwater Ecol & Inland Fisheries I,
   Muggelseedamm 310, Berlin, D-12587, Germany, Germany.
EM j.freyhof@igb-berlin.de
RI Kaya, Cuneyt/N-1415-2015
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Oxynoemacheilus kentritensis [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Balitoridae
OR Oxynoemacheilus frenatus - (Heckel 1843) (Balitoridae): [Systematics, P.
   555]. 
   Oxynoemacheilus kentritensis (Balitoridae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 552].

PT J

PM 28609899
DT Article
TI Two new species of the genus Sinopodisma Chang, 1940 (Orthoptra,
   Acridoidea, Catantopidae, Podisminae) from Taiwan, China.
AU Ye, Bao-Hua
   Shi, Jian-Ping
   Yin, Zhan (yinzhan@hbu.edu.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 6
PS 574-578
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species of the genus Sinopodisma Chang, 1940 from Taiwan, China
   are described in this paper. The new species Sinopodisma orchofemura sp.
   nov. is similar to Sinopodisma kodamae (Shiraki, 1910), but differs from
   latter in antennae length of joint 2.9 times width in the middle part,
   hind femur yellow, length of interspace of mesosternum larger than
   narrowest, tegmina almost reaching the hind margin of second abdominal
   tergum. The Sinopodisma hsinchuensis sp. nov. is similar to Sinopodisma
   orchofemura sp. nov., but differs from latter by vertical diameter of
   eyes 1.7 times horizontal diameter and 1.8 times subocular furrow;
   tegmina extending over the hind margin of first abdominal tergite
   slightly; the length of interspace of mesosternum equal to narrowest and
   subgenital plate longer than ovipositor valves ventral view. Type
   specimens are deposited in the National Museum of Natural Science,
   Taichung, Taiwan, China and the Institute of Entomology, Taiwan
   University, Taibei, Taiwan, China respectively.
C1 Yin, Zhan; Hebei Univ, Coll Life Sci, Baoding, 071002, China, China.
EM yinzhan@hbu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Sinopodisma hsinchuensis; Sinopodisma orchofemura [Taiwan /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Sinopodisma hsinchuensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 576]. 
   Sinopodisma kodamae - (Shiraki 1910) (Saltatoria): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 576]. 
   Sinopodisma orchofemura (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 574]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15307045609
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15307045611
PM 28609901
DT Article
TI Description of Diploplastron dehorityi sp nov (Entodiniomorphida,
   Ophryoscolecidae), a new rumen ciliate from Brazilian sheep (Ovis
   aries).
AU Cedrola, Franciane (francedrola@gmail.com) 
   Pedroso Dias, Roberto Junio
   Martinele, Isabel
   D'Agosto, Marta
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 6
PS 581-585
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB To date the genus Diploplastron comprised only one species of
   ophryoscolecid ciliate, Diploplastron affine, which is characterized by
   having two retractable ciliary zones in the anterior end of the body,
   two slender and juxtaposed skeletal plates on the right side, a rod
   shape macronucleus, and two contractile vacuoles. During study on the
   characterization of rumen ciliate community composition in Brazilian
   domestic sheep, we observed ciliates with atypical morphology but with
   diagnostic features of genus Diploplastron. This study describes
   Diploplastron dehorityi, a new species of ophryoscolecid ciliate, that
   differs from D. affine, primarily, in the morphology of skeletal plates,
   morphology of nuclear apparatus and body shape. In addition to the
   similarities between the new species and congener species, D. dehorityi
   has some morphological similarities to species of genus Eremoplastron.
C1 Cedrola, Franciane; Univ Fed Juiz Fora, Inst Ciencias Biol, Campus Univ,
   Juiz De Fora, Minas Gerais, BR-36036900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM francedrola@gmail.com
RI Cedrola, Franciane/AAB-2658-2019; D` Agosto, Marta/V-2895-2017
OI Cedrola, Franciane/0000-0002-5170-656X; D` Agosto,
   Marta/0000-0003-3654-3528
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Diploplastron dehorityi [Associations / Ovis aries (Mammalia) / New
   associate species] [Brazil /  / New species; mammalian associate]. 
   Ovis aries [Associations / Diploplastron dehorityi (Protozoa) / New
   associate species] [Brazil /  / New associated protozoan species]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Protozoans; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Bovidae,
   Protozoa, Ciliophora, Kinetofragminophorea, Vestibuliferia,
   Entodiniomorphida
OR Ovis aries (Bovidae). 
   Diploplastron dehorityi (Entodiniomorphida): [Sp nov, Brazil, Associated
   with Ovis aries (Mammalia), p. 582]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15307045611
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15408045652
DT Article
TI A new species in the genus Copaxa WALKER, 1855 from Ecuador
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Eine neue Art der Gattung Copaxa WALKER, 1855 aus Ecuador (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Kaech, Horst
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 10
IS 2
PS 5-7
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species in the genus Copaxa WALKER, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from Ecuador, Morona Santiago province, is described and
   figured: C. pinasi n. sp. The holotype is deposited in coll. Ronald
   BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), in coll. Museum Wrrr, Munich (Germany), which
   later, together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlung Munchen, Munich, Germany. The male and the preimaginal
   instars of this new species are unknown. Furthermore, recent DNA-barcode
   studies revealed that the type series of C. simoni BRECHLIN, KACH &
   MEISTER, 2011 from Morona Santiago province (Ecuador) consists of two
   species: C. simoni and the herein described C. pinasi n. sp. In
   addition, these studies also indicated that the HT-[female](BC-RBP
   10406) of C. simoni and the HT-[female] (BC-HKT 0149) of C. hoehni
   BRECHLIN, KACH & MEISTER, 2013 syn. nov. are conspecific. Consequently,
   C. hoehni syn. nov. should now be treated as a junior subjective synonym
   of C. simoni.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Friedberg 20, Pasewalk, D-17309, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Copaxa pinasi [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Copaxa pinasi (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 5]. 
   Copaxa simoni - Brechlin, Kaech & Meister 2011 (Saturniidae): [Syn nov,
   Copaxa hoehni Brechlin, Kaech & Meister 2013, p. 6]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15408045652
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A new species in the genus Phanoxyla ROTHSCHILD & JORDAN, 1903 from
   Colombia (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae).
FT Eine neue Art der Gattung Phanoxyla ROTHSCHILD & JORDAN, 1903 aus
   Kolumbien (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 10
IS 2
PS 8-9
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A second species in the genus Phanoxyla ROTHSCHILD & JORDAN, 1903
   (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae) from Colombia (Antioquia dept.) is described
   and figured: Phanoxyla kitchingi n. sp. The holotype [male] is deposited
   in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), in coll. Museum Wirr, Munich
   (which will be incorporated into the Zoologische Staatssammlung
   MUnchen/Munich, Germany). The new species can be distinguished from the
   hitherto only known species in that genus, P. hystrix (FELDER & FELDER,
   1874) with its type locality in the Amazonian area in Brazil, by several
   external characters. The female and the preimaginal instars of the new
   taxon are unknown.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Friedberg 20, Pasewalk, D-17309, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Phanoxyla kitchingi [Colombia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Sphingoidea, Sphingidae
OR Phanoxyla kitchingi (Sphingidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 8].

LA German

AB A new taxon in the genus Actias LEACH in LEACH & NODDER, 1815 from C
   Vietnam is described and figured: A. sinensis siriae n. ssp. The
   holotype [male] in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), is deposited
   in coll. Museum Wrrr, Munich (and will finally be included in the
   Zoologische Staatssammlung Munchen (Munich), Germany). A checklist of
   the Actias sinensis WALKER, 1855-species complex is given.

TI Seventeen new species in the genus Dirphia HUEBNER, 1819 ('1816')
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Siebzehn neue Arten der Gattung Dirphia HUEBNER, 1819 ('1816')
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 10
IS 2
PS 14-37
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
NT With contributions from: Drechsel, U., Meister, F. & Kaech, H.
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Seventeen new species in the genus Dirphia HUBNER, 1819 ( 1816")
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) are described and figured: D. aviconcepciona
   BRECHLIN & DRECHSEL n. sp. (type locality: Paraguay (Concepcion)), D.
   avirosensis BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Costa,Rica (Cuanacaste)), D.
   rubriconcepciona BRECHLIN & DRECHSEL n. sp. (Paraguay (Concepcion)), D.
   radiatoides BRECHLIN n. sp. (French Guiana (Cayenne)), D. radandensis
   BRECHLIN n. sp. (Peru (Loreto)), D. panguana BRECHLIN n. sp. (Peru
   (Huanuco)), D. chanchamayensis BRECHLIN n. sp. (Peru (Junin)), D.
   durangensis BRECHLIN n. sp. (Ecuador (Esmeraldas)), D. diana BRECHLIN n.
   sp. (Colombia (Antioquia)), D. simbanai BRECHLIN & KACH n. sp. (Ecuador
   (Napo)), D. santboyacensis BRECHLIN n. sp. (Colombia (Boyaca)), D.
   crassgachala BRECHLIN n. sp. (Colombia (Cundinamarca)), D. yarumala
   BRECHLIN n. sp. (Colombia (Antioquia)), D. ludyarumala BRECHLIN n. sp.
   (Colombia (Antioquia)), D. sachai BRECHLIN & KAcft n. sp. (Ecuador
   (Sucumblos)), D. riekerti BRECHLIN n. sp. (French Guiana (Cayenne)) and
   D. rougeriei BRECHLIN n. sp. (French Guiana (Cayenne)). All holotype c5
   are deposited in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), in coll. Museum
   Win, Munich (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will
   be included in Zoologische Staatssammlung Miinchen, Munich, Germany.
   Some preimaginal instars of D. sachai n. sp., D. napoensis RACHELI &
   RACHELI, 2005, D. nora (DRUCE, 1897) and D. somoccidentalis BRECHLIN,
   KACH & MEISTER, 2013 are illustrated.

PT J
AN ZOOR15408045656
DT Article
TI Notes on the genus Paradirphia MICHENER, 1949 with descriptions of
   nineteen new taxa (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Einige Anmerkungen zur Gattung Paradirphia MICHENER, 1949 mit
   Beschreibungen von neunzehn neuen Taxa (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 10
IS 2
PS 38-56
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nineteen new taxa in the genus Paradirphia MICHENER, 1949 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured (names are followed by the type
   locality in the format: country (province/department/state)):
   Paradirphia elongata n. sp. (Mexico (Puebla)), P. pueblonuevensis n. sp.
   (Mexico (Chiapas)), P. sanpedrensis n. sp. (Mexico (Oaxaca)), P.
   sangabrielensis n. sp. (Mexico (Oaxaca)), P. mirador n. sp. (Mexico
   (Chiapas)), P. parapeggyae n. sp. (Honduras (Ocotepeque)), P.
   parapeggyae lempirensis n. ssp. (Honduras (Lempira)), P. alajuelensis n.
   sp. (Costa Rica (Alajuela)), F vanschaycki n. sp. (Mexico (Oaxaca)), P.
   yagulana n. sp. (Mexico (Oaxaca)), P. cholulensis n. sp. (Mexico
   (Puebla)), P. angelensis n. sp. (Mexico (Oaxaca)), P. potosiana n. sp.
   (Mexico (San Luis Potosi)), P. tatama n. sp. (Colombia (Risaralda)), P.
   tolima n. sp. (Colombia (Tolima)), P. caldas n. sp. (Colombia (Caldas)),
   P. cabrera n. sp. (Colombia (Tolima)), P. santander n. sp. (Colombia
   (Santander)) and P. cavichensis n. sp. (Colombia (Boyaca)). All
   holotypes are deposited in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk, Germany
   (CRBP), in coll. Museum Wrrr, Munich (Germany), which later, together
   with this collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlung
   Mfinchen, Munich, Germany. In addition, P. michoacana BEUTELSPACHER,
   1984 stat. rev. is removed from synonymy with P. fumosa (FELDER &
   FELDER, 1875) and reinstated to species status. Furthermore, subsequent
   DNA-barcode studies revealed that the holotypes of R leoni BRECHLIN &
   MEISTER, 2010 syn. nov. and P. frankae BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2010 belong
   to one species. Because P. leoni and P. frankae were described within
   the same publication (BRECHLIN & MEISTER 2010), we here act as "First
   Reviser" (Article 24.2.2. of ICZN 1999) to assign the priority of P.
   frankae over P leoni syn. nov. The of P. lieseorum BRECHLIN & MEISTER,
   2010 is figured (Abb. 15 & 16) for the first time. The invalidity of the
   name Dirphia semirosea apollinairei BOUVIER, 1930 (compare LEMAIRE 2002:
   700 (= synonym of Paradirphia antonia (DoGNiN, 1911))) is discussed. In
   our opinion in BOUVIER (1930: 56) there is a description of a (Abb. 30)
   only without giving any new name baring status. Due to SCHOSSLER (1934:
   422) it could be a new combination of Pseudodirphia apollinairei
   BOUVIER, 1929. The latter one is today a synonym of Pseudodirphia
   pallida (WALKER, 1865).
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Friedberg 20, Pasewalk, D-17309, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North America; Central America;
   South America
DE Paradirphia alajuelensis [Costa Rica /  / New species]. 
   Paradirphia angelensis; Paradirphia cholulensis; Paradirphia elongata;
   Paradirphia mirador; Paradirphia potosiana; Paradirphia pueblonuevensis;
   Paradirphia sangabrielensis; Paradirphia sanpedrensis; Paradirphia
   vanschaycki; Paradirphia yagulana [Mexico /  / New species]. 
   Paradirphia cabrera; Paradirphia caldas; Paradirphia cavichensis;
   Paradirphia santander; Paradirphia tatama; Paradirphia tolima [Colombia
   /  / New species]. 
   Paradirphia parapeggyae [Honduras /  / New species]. 
   Paradirphia parapeggyae lempirensis [Honduras /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Dirphia semirosea apollinairei - Bouvier 1930 (Saturniidae):
   [Unavailable name, P. 48]. 
   Paradirphia alajuelensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Costa Rica, P. 42]. 
   Paradirphia angelensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 44]. 
   Paradirphia cabrera (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 46]. 
   Paradirphia caldas (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 46]. 
   Paradirphia cavichensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 47]. 
   Paradirphia cholulensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 44]. 
   Paradirphia elongata (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 39]. 
   Paradirphia frankae - Brechlin & Meister 2010 (Saturniidae): [Syn nov,
   Paradirphia leoni Brechlin & Meister 2010, p. 48]. 
   Paradirphia fumosa - (Felder & Felder 1875) (Saturniidae): [Removal from

   Paradirphia lieseorum - Brechlin & Meister 2010 (Saturniidae): [First
   time described, Male, p. 41; First time figured, Male, p. 51]. 
   Paradirphia michoacana - Beutelspacher 1984 (Saturniidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Paradirphia fumosa (Felder & Felder 1875), p. 45]. 
   Paradirphia mirador (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 40]. 
   Paradirphia parapeggyae (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Honduras, P. 41]. 
   Paradirphia parapeggyae lempirensis (Saturniidae): [Subsp nov, Honduras,
   P. 41]. 
   Paradirphia potosiana (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 45]. 
   Paradirphia pueblonuevensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 39]. 
   Paradirphia sangabrielensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 40]. 
   Paradirphia sanpedrensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 39]. 
   Paradirphia santander (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 47]. 
   Paradirphia tatama (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 45]. 
   Paradirphia tolima (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 46]. 
   Paradirphia vanschaycki (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 43]. 
   Paradirphia yagulana (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 44].

PT J

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Gamelioides LEMAIRE, 1988 from Peru
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Eine neue Art der Gattung Gamelioides LEMAIRE, 1988 aus Peru
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de)

AB A new species in the genus Gamelioides LEMAIRE, 1988 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from Peru (Junin dept.) is described and figured: G.
   antkozlovi n. sp. The holotype is deposited in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN,

DT Article
TI Sixteen new taxa in the genus Automeris HUEBNER, 1819 ('1816')
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Sechzehn neue Taxa der Gattung Automeris HUEBNER, 1819 ('1816')
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
   Kaech, Horst
   van Schayck, Eric
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 10
IS 2
PS 60-82
PD May 3 2017
PY 2017
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Sixteen new taxa in the genus Automeris HUBNER, 1819 ( 1816")
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) are described and figured: Automeris
   handschugi BRECHLIN n. sp. (type locality: Colombia (Boyaca)), A. lapaza
   BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Bolivia (La Paz)), A. andensis BRECHLIN &
   KAcH n. sp. (Ecuador (Sucumbios)), A. despicatoides BRECHLIN & VAN
   SCHAYCK n. sp. (Peru (Junin)), A. comayaguana BRECHLIN n. sp. (Honduras
   (Comayagua)), A. fieldi fieldseptentrides BRECHLIN n. ssp. (Colombia
   (Boyaca)), A. galecio BRECHLIN & KACH n. sp. (Ecuador (Sucumbios)), A.
   juliae BRECHLIN & KAcH n. sp. (Ecuador (Sucumbios)), A. vincentensis
   BRECHLIN n. sp. (Colombia (Risaralda)), A. sarapiqui BRECHLIN & MEISTER
   n. sp. (Costa Rica (Heredia)), A. tuxlana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp.
   (Mexico (Chiapas)), A. chanchamayensis BRECHLIN & VAN SCHAYCK n. sp.
   (Peru (Junin)), A. dunschei BRECHLIN & VAN SCHAYCK n. sp. (Bolivia (La
   Paz)), A. isabellae BRECHLIN & KAcH n. sp. (Ecuador (Carchi)), A.
   arminandensis BRECHLIN & KACH n. sp. (Ecuador (Orellana)) and A.
   luciorum BRECHLIN & VAN SCHAYCK n. sp. (Costa Rica (Puntarenas)). All
   holotypes are deposited in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), in
   coll. Museum Wm, Munich (Germany), which later, together with this
   collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlung Miinchen,
   Munich, Germany. Furthermore, Automeris despicata santaclariana BRECHLIN
   & MEISTER, 2011 stat. nov., recently (BENELuz 2013) synonymizedwithA.
   despicataDRAUDT, 1929, is reinstated as a subspecies of that species.
   Also A. fieldi cinctinicaraguana BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2011 syn. & stat.
   nov. is treated as subspecies of A. fieldi LEMAIRE, 1969. Within the
   context of the description of A. f fieldseptentrides n. ssp. the
   possible conspecificity of A. fieldi and A. cinctistriga (FELDER &
   FELDER, (1874)) is discussed. Similarly, the possible conspecificity of
   A. ecuata BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2011 with A. atrolimbata LEMAIRE, 1973 is
   discussed. However, in neither case is an explicit status change made.
   The very probable female of A. cuscosylviae BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2011
   (Abb. 4; BC (barcode in BOLD)-RBP 8062"; but from Ecuador (Zamora
   Chinchipe)) is illustrated. In addition, the likely female of A.
   pichichensis LEMAIRE, 1976 is correctly figured for the first time the
   illustrated y of "pichichensis" in LEMAIRE 2002 (pl. 56: 6) from East
   Ecuador is probably a of A. parecuata BRECHLIN, KAcH & MEISTER, 2013.
   Additionally, the following two errors are corrected. Reexamination of
   the type series of A. pinasiana BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2014, revealed that
   it included not only specimens from the SW Ecuadorian province of El Oro
   and the Colombian department of Choc6 (BRECHLIN & MEISTER 2014: 14) but
   also that some of the paratypes actually came from Costa Rica (Cartago
   and Limon provinces). This was overlooked in the description of this
   species and extends its range into Central America. Second, the stated
   altitude of "2000 m" for the type locality of A. barinasmargaritae
   BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2011 (BRECHLIN & MEISTER 2011: 33) is clearly wrong!
   The Barinas" locality of Bernhard WENCZEL (Switzerland) is correctly:
   "Venezuela, Barinas, Barinitas, Rio Calderas, 420 m" (e.g. compare
   BRECHLIN et al. 2016: 18).
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Friedberg 20, Pasewalk, D-17309, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de

AB Six new species in the genus Cerodirphia MICHENER, 1949 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured: C. pruvoti BRECHLIN, MEISTER &
   VAN SCHAYCK n. sp. (type locality: French Guiana (Cayenne)), C.
   paraspeciosa BRECHLIN n. sp. (French Guiana (Cayenne)), C.
   altoparanensis BRECHLIN & DRECHSEL n. sp. (Paraguay (Alto Parana)), C.
   panguana BRECHLIN n. sp. (Peru (Huanuco)), C. amamartinensis BRECHLIN n.
   sp. (Peru (San Martin)) and C. gachala BRECHLIN n. sp. (Colombia
   (Cundinamarca)). All holotypes are deposited in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN,
   Pasewalk (CRBP), in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later,
   together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlung Miinchen, Munich, Germany. The preimaginal instars of all
   new taxa are unknown.

AB Platyptilia galicicaensis sp. n. (Pterophoridae) is described. The
   species is found in the Republic of Macedonia, Ohrid, Galicica National
   Park. All specimens were collected around Helichrysum zivojini
   Cernjavski & Soska, 1940 or H. stoechas (L.) Moench, 1794 (Asteraceae);
   one or both of these plants is probably the host plant of the new
   species.

PM 28463233
DT Article
TI Mosaic evolution in an asymmetrically feathered troodontid dinosaur with
   transitional features.
AU Xu, Xing (xu.xing@ivpp.ac.cn) 
   Currie, Philip
   Pittman, Michael
   Xing, Lida
   Meng, Qingjin
   Lu, Junchang
   Hu, Dongyu
   Yu, Congyu
SO Nature Communications
VL 8
PS 14972
PD May 2 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 34
AB Asymmetrical feathers have been associated with flight capability but
   are also found in species that do not fly, and their appearance was a
   major event in feather evolution. Among non-avialan theropods, they are
   only known in microraptorine dromaeosaurids. Here we report a new
   troodontid, Jianianhualong tengi gen. et sp. nov., from the Lower
   Cretaceous Jehol Group of China, that has anatomical features that are
   transitional between long-armed basal troodontids and derived
   short-armed ones, shedding new light on troodontid character evolution.
   It indicates that troodontid feathering is similar to Archaeopteryx in
   having large arm and leg feathers as well as frond-like tail feathering,
   confirming that these feathering characteristics were widely present
   among basal paravians. Most significantly, the taxon has the earliest
   known asymmetrical troodontid feathers, suggesting that feather
   asymmetry was ancestral to Paraves. This taxon also displays a mosaic
   distribution of characters like Sinusonasus, another troodontid with
   transitional anatomical features.
C1 Xu, Xing; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Vertebrate Paleontol & Paleoanthropol,
   Beijing, 100044, China, China.
EM xu.xing@ivpp.ac.cn
RI Pittman, Michael/F-9779-2012
OI Pittman, Michael/0000-0002-6149-3078
SC Zoology
SN 2041-1723

   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Jianianhualong [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Jianianhualong tengi [Liaoning /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Theropoda
OR Jianianhualong (Theropoda): [Gen nov, Of family Troodontidae, Type
   species Jianianhualong tengi, p. 2, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Jianianhualong tengi (Theropoda): [Sp nov, Liaoning, Cretaceous, P. 2;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15401000631
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15311070259
PM 28480136
DT Article
TI The earliest known titanosauriform sauropod dinosaur and the evolution
   of Brachiosauridae.
AU Mannion, Philip D. (philipdman-nion@gmail.com) 
   Allain, Ronan
   Moine, Olivier
SO PeerJ
VL 5
PS e3217
PD May 2 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Brachiosauridae is a clade of titanosauriform sauropod dinosaurs that
   includes the wellknown Late Jurassic taxa Brachiosaurus and
   Giraffatitan. However, there is disagreement over the brachiosaurid
   affinities of most other taxa, and little consensus regarding the
   clade's composition or inter-relationships. An unnamed partial sauropod
   skeleton was collected from middle-late Oxfordian (early Late Jurassic)
   deposits in Damparis, in the Jura department of eastern France, in 1934.
   Since its brief description in 1943, this specimen has been informally
   known in the literature as the ' Damparis sauropod' and ' French
   Bothriospondylus', and has been considered a brachiosaurid by most
   authors. If correctly identified, this would make the specimen the
   earliest known titanosauriform. Coupled with its relatively complete
   nature and the rarity of Oxfordian sauropod remains in general, this is
   an important specimen for understanding the early evolution of
   Titanosauriformes. Full preparation and description of this specimen,
   known from teeth, vertebrae and most of the appendicular skeleton of a
   single individual, recognises it as a distinct taxon: Vouivria
   damparisensis gen. et sp. nov. Phylogenetic analysis of a data matrix
   comprising 77 taxa (including all putative brachiosaurids) scored for
   416 characters recovers a fairly well resolved Brachiosauridae. Vouivria
   is a basal brachiosaurid, confirming its status as the stratigraphically
   oldest known titanosauriform. Brachiosauridae consists of a paraphyletic
   array of Late Jurassic forms, with Europasaurus, Vouivria and
   Brachiosaurus recovered as successively more nested genera that lie
   outside of a clade comprising (Giraffatitan + Sonorasaurus) + (Lusotitan
   + (Cedarosaurus + Venenosaurus)). Abydosaurus forms an unresolved
   polytomy with the latter five taxa. The Early Cretaceous South American
   sauropod Padillasaurus was previously regarded as a brachiosaurid, but
   is here placed within Somphospondyli. A recent study contended that a
   number of characters used in a previous iteration of this data matrix
   are ' biologically related', and thus should be excluded from
   phylogenetic analysis. We demonstrate that almost all of these
   characters show variation between taxa, and implementation of
   sensitivity analyses, in which these characters are excluded, has no
   effect on tree topology or resolution. We argue that where there is
   morphological variation, this should be captured, rather than ignored.
   Unambiguous brachiosaurid remains are known only from the USA, western
   Europe and Africa, and the clade spanned the Late Jurassic through to
   the late Albian/early Cenomanian, with the last known occurrences all
   from the USA. Regardless of whether their absence from the Cretaceous of
   Europe, as well as other regions entirely, reflects regional extinctions
   and genuine absences, or sampling artefacts, brachiosaurids appear to
   have become globally extinct by the earliest Late Cretaceous.
C1 Mannion, Philip D.; Imperial Coll London, Dept Earth Sci & Engn, London,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM philipdman-nion@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 2167-8359
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Evolution; Zoogeography;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Brachiosauridae [Evolution / Evolutionary history / systematics]
   [Zoogeography / Palaeobiogeography / ]. 
   Titanosauriformes [France /  / systematics; oldest record] [Jurassic /
   Oxfordian / ]. 
   Vouivria [Jurassic /  / New genus]. 
   Vouivria damparisensis [France /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Sauropodomorpha
OR Brachiosauridae (Sauropodomorpha). 
   Europasaurus (Sauropodomorpha): [Taxonomic position, P. 67]. 
   Padillasaurus (Sauropodomorpha): [Taxonomic position, P. 68]. 
   Titanosauriformes - Salgado, Coria & Calvo 1997 (Sauropodomorpha):
   [Fossil]. 
   Vouivria (Sauropodomorpha): [Gen nov, Of family Brachiosauridae, Type
   species Vouivria damparisensis, p. 13, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Vouivria damparisensis (Sauropodomorpha): [Sp nov, France, Jurassic, P.
   13; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15311070259
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15311070257
PM 28480132
DT Article
TI Osteology of Galeamopus pabsti sp. nov. (Sauropoda: Diplodocidae), with
   implications for neurocentral closure timing, and the cervico-dorsal
   transition in diplodocids.
AU Tschopp, Emanuel (tschopp.e@gmail.com) 
   Mateus, Octavio
SO PeerJ
VL 5
PS e3179
PD May 2 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Diplodocids are among the best known sauropod dinosaurs. Numerous
   specimens of currently 15 accepted species belonging to ten genera have
   been reported from the Late Jurassic to Early Cretaceous of North and
   South America, Europe, and Africa. The highest diversity is known from
   the Upper Jurassic Morrison Formation of the western United States: a
   recent review recognized 12 valid, named species, and possibly three
   additional, yet unnamed ones. One of these is herein described in detail
   and referred to the genus Galeamopus. The holotype specimen of
   Galeamopuspabstisp. nov., SMA 0011, is represented by material from all
   body parts but the tail, and was found at the Howe-Scott Quarry in the
   northern Bighorn Basin in Wyoming, USA. Autapomorphic features of the
   new species include a horizontal canal on the maxilla that connects the
   posterior margin of the preantorbital and the ventral margin of the
   antorbital fenestrae, a vertical midline groove marking the sagittal
   nuchal crest, the presence of a large foramen connecting the
   postzygapophyseal centrodiapophyseal fossa and the
   spinopostzygapophyseal fossa of mid- and posterior cervical vertebrae, a
   very robust humerus, a laterally placed, rugose tubercle on the concave
   proximal portion of the anterior surface of the humerus, a relatively
   stout radius, the absence of a distinct ambiens process on the pubis,
   and a distinctly concave posteroventral margin of the ascending process
   of the astragalus. In addition to the holotype specimen SMA 0011, the
   skull USNM 2673 can also be referred to Galeamopuspabsti. Histology
   shows that the type specimen SMA 0011 is sexually mature, although
   neurocentral closure was not completed at the time of death. Because SMA
   0011 has highly pneumatized cervical vertebrae, the development of the
   lamination appears a more important indicator for individual age than
   neurocentral fusion patterns. SMA 0011 is one of very few sauropod
   specimens that preserves the cervico-dorsal transition in both vertebrae
   and ribs. The association of ribs with their respective vertebrae shows
   that the transition between cervical and dorsal vertebrae is
   significantly different in Galeamopuspabsti than in Diplodocuscarnegiior
   Apatosauruslouisae, being represented by a considerable shortening of
   the centra from the last cervical to the first dorsal vertebra.
   Diplodocids show a surprisingly high diversity in the Morrison
   Formation. This can possibly be explained by a combination of
   geographical and temporal segregation, and niche partitioning.
C1 Tschopp, Emanuel; Univ Turin, Dipartimento Sci Terra, Turin, Italy,
   Italy.
EM tschopp.e@gmail.com
RI Tschopp, Emanuel/H-2723-2019; Mateus, Octavio/F-2910-2010
OI Tschopp, Emanuel/0000-0002-5245-6910; Mateus,
   Octavio/0000-0003-1253-3616
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 2167-8359

   development; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA;

   / ]. 
   Galeamopus pabsti [Colorado /  / new species] [Wyoming /  / ] [Jurassic
   /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Sauropodomorpha
OR Diplodocidae (Sauropodomorpha): [Fossil]. 
   Galeamopus - Tschopp, Mateus & Benson 2015 (Sauropodomorpha): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 6]. 
   Galeamopus hayi - (Holland 1924) (Sauropodomorpha): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 7].

DT Article
TI Further records on the plant bug tribe Hallodapini (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera: Miridae: Phylinae) in Asia, with proposition of two new
   species and a new synonymy.
AU Duwal, Ram Keshari (ramkeshariduwal@gmail.com) 
   Yasunaga, Tomohide
   Tomokuni, Masaaki
   Nakatani, Yukinobu
   Hirowatari, Toshiya
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 5
PS 401-424
PD May 2 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A total of twelve species in five genera belonging to the phyline plant
   bug tribe Hallodapini are treated. Two new species are described from
   Indochina: Cleotomiris inthanon Duwal & Yasunaga sp.nov. (Thailand) and
   Cleotomiroides vietnamensis Duwal & Yasunaga sp. nov. (Vietnam). New
   distributional records are also presented for some known species of
   Hallodapus Fieber and Wygomiris Schuh. Hallodapus persimilis (Poppius)
   is proposed as a junior synonym of H. ravenar (Poppius). Illustrations
   of the endosoma for four species, including the new species, are
   presented. Digital images of the male genitalic structures are shown for
   nine species, including the two new species, and also female genitalic
   structures of the species of Cleotomiris Schuh, Cleotomiroides Schuh and
   Wygomiris Schuh, are provided. The immature forms are documented for the
   first time for Acrorrhinium inexpectatum (Josifov) and Wygomiris
   kaliyahae Yasunaga.

DT Article
TI Systematic revision of the Andean butterfly genus Orophila Staudinger,
   1886 (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae: Biblidinae).
AU Zubek, Anna (anna_zubek@hotmail.com) 
   Pyrcz, Tomasz
   Lorenc-Brudecka, Jadwiga
   Boyer, Pierre
   Cerdena, Jose
   Mahecha-Jimenez, Oscar
   Huertas, Blanca
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 5
PS 443-461
PD May 2 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A systematic review of the Neotropical butterfly genus Orophila
   Staudinger, 1886 based on morphological characters and geographical
   distribution is presented. Four species are recognized: O. campaspe
   (Hewitson, 1869) stat. rest., O. cardases (Hewitson, 1869), O. cecidas
   (Hewitson, 1869) stat. rest. and O. diotima (Hewitson, 1852). Other
   changes proposed include treating Orophila diotima footei (Lamas, 2003)
   syn. n. and O. cardases zurita (Fruhstorfer, 1916) syn. n. as synonyms
   of other taxa. Illustrations of adult males and male genitalia of all
   taxa are presented and the importance of morphological characters in
   both males and females is evaluated. Female specimens and genitalia are
   illustrated for the first time for O. c. cardases, O. cecidas and O.
   diotima. Lectotypes are designated for two nominal taxa.
C1 Zubek, Anna; Jagiellonian Univ, Inst Zool, Gronostajowa 9, Krakow,
   PL-30387, Poland, Poland.
EM anna_zubek@hotmail.com

AB A new monotypic genus of scutacarid mites, Gerdalbertia gen. nov.
   (Acari: Pygmephoroidea: Scutacaridae), with type species G. elongata sp.

PM 28609908
DT Article
TI Scale insects (Hemiptera: Coccomorpha) on sugarcane in Colombia, with
   description of a new species of Tillancoccus Ben-Dov (Coccidae).
AU Caballero, Alejandro (lacaballeror@unal.edu.co) 
   Amalia Ramos-Portilla, Andrea
   Kondo, Takumasa
SO Zootaxa
VL 4258
IS 5
PS 490-500
PD May 2 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Herein we describe a new species, Tillancoccus koreguajae Caballero &
   Ramos, sp. n. (Hemiptera: Coccidae) from Colombia collected on
   sugarcane. Pinnaspis strachani (Cooley) is also recorded on sugarcane
   for the first time worldwide. An updated list of seven species of
   Coccomorpha on sugarcane in Colombia is provided, including information
   on its distribution, biology, and mutualistic ants for each species.
   Seven species of scale insects (Hemiptera: Coccomorpha) have been
   recorded previously on sugarcane, Saccharum officinarum L. (Poaceae) in
   Colombia: Pseudococcidae: Dysmicoccus boninsis (Kuwana), D. brevipes
   (Cockerell), Pseudococcus calceolariae (Maskell), Saccharicoccus
   sacchari (Cockerell); Coccidae: Pulvinaria elongata Newstead;
   Diaspididae: Duplachionaspis divergens (Green) and Serenaspis minima
   (Maskell). However, the record of S. minima in Colombia is considered
   doubtful as there are no voucher specimens from Colombia and because the
   distribution of this species is currently limited to the Australasian
   region. Pseudococcus calceolariae is present in Colombia but its record
   on sugarcane is also doubtful. A taxonomic key for the identification of
   scale insects on sugarcane in Colombia is provided.
C1 Caballero, Alejandro; Univ Nacl Colombia, Fac Ciencias Agr, Bogota,
   Colombia, Colombia.
EM lacaballeror@unal.edu.co
RI Caballero, Alejandro/N-2283-2019
OI Caballero, Alejandro/0000-0001-8237-4978

DT Article
TI A new spider of the genus Cicurina from a limestone cave on
   Minami-daito-jima Island, Okinawa, Japan.
AU Shimojana, Matsuei
   Ono, Hirotsugu (ono@kahaku.go.jp) 
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
VL 43
IS 2
PS 81-86
PD May 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Cicurina Menge, 1871 (Araneae, Cicurininae)
   is described from Hoshino-do Cave on Minami-daito-jima Island, Okinawa
   Prefecture, Japan, under the name of Cicurina hoshinonoana sp. nov. The
   new species is closely related to Cicurina maculifera Yaginuma, 1979
   known from Katano-do Cave, Shibushi-cho, Kagoshima Prefecture, southern
   Kyushu, but differs from the latter by the shape of the male palpal
   organ and the structure of female genitalia. Eyes of males of the new
   spider show degeneration.

TI Conspicuum aliraazi n. sp. (Trematode: Dicroglossidae) from Common Myna
   (Acridotheres tristis) of district Larkana, Sindh, Pakistan.
AU Soomro, Bakhtawar
   Gachal, Ghulam Sarwar
   Shaikh, Yusuf
   Narejo, Naeem Tariq
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 5
IS 3 P
PS 1106-1109
PD May 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new trematode C. aliraazi n. sp. is described from the gall bladder of
   A. tristis of District Larkana, Sindh, Pakistan. In all, 03 trematodes;
   one new species C. aliraazi was recorded. The present trematode differs
   from its allies in the body shape; size; presence of sub-terminal oral
   sucker; wider ventral sucker; position of testes and distribution of
   uterus. On the basis of such morpho-metrical diversification, the new
   species C. aliraazi has been proposed. The authoress dedicates new
   species in the honour and name of her elder brother Mr. Ali Raza Soomro.
C1 Soomro, Bakhtawar; Univ Sindh, Dept Zool, Jamshoro, Pakistan, Pakistan.

PT J
AN ZOOR15404020294
DT Article
TI Biological characterization and identification of bacteria from
   Misgurnus anguillicaudatus associated with body surface hemorrhagic
   disease.
AU Lin Feng
   Liu Li
   Bao Chengrong
   Wang Yuchen
   Cao Zheng
   Xu Yang
   Li Qian
   Hu Tingjian (wwlinfeng@163.com) 
SO Anhui Nongye Daxue Xuebao
VL 44
IS 3
PS 367-372
PD May 2017
PY 2017
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two bacteria associated with body surface hemorrhagic disease were
   isolated from the blood, heart, liver, spleen, intestines of Misgurnus
   anguillicaudatus, which were further analyzed using morphological
   observation, physiological and biochemical characteristic analysis,
   16SrDNA sequence determination, sensitivity test and artificial
   infection experiments. The isolated strains were identified as Vibrio
   cholerae and Shewanella putrefaciens which were related to the
   pathogenicity of Misgurnus anguillicaudatus. The sensitivity of the two
   bacteria to 20 antibiotics was evaluated. The results showed that the
   isolated strains were highly sensitive to seven antibiotics including
   chloramphenicol, ceftazidime pentahydrate, norfloxacin, tetracycline,
   cefoxitin, paediatric compound sulfamethoxazole and ciprofloxacin. They
   also showed some resistance to other antibiotics. This is the first
   report on a new pathogen of Misgurnus anguillicaudatus. It revealed that
   Shewanella sp., as a potential new pathogen, may have a synergistic
   effect with Vibrio cholerae and pose a threat to the culture of
   Misgurnus anguillicaudatus.
C1 Hu Tingjian; Zhejiang Inst Freshwater Fisheries, Minist Agr, Huzhou,
   313001, China, China.
EM wwlinfeng@163.com
SC Infectious Diseases; Zoology
SN 1672-352X
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Diseases and disorders; Microbial
   diseases
DE Misgurnus anguillicaudatus [Bacterial diseases / Shewanella putrefaciens
   / New record] [ / Vibrio cholerae / Pathology; biological
   characterization & identification; body surface haemorrhagic disease]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cobitidae
OR Misgurnus anguillicaudatus (Cobitidae).

AN ZOOR15404023330
DT Article
TI Revision of the genera Lysceia Walker and Pasteosia Hampson
   (Lepidoptera: Erebidae: Arctiinae: Lithosiini).
AU Kruger, M. (kruger@ditsong.org.za) 
SO Annals of the Ditsong National Museum of Natural History
VL 7
PS 8-96
PD May 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The endemic southern African footman genera Lysceia Walker, 1854 and
   Pasteosia Hampson, 1900 are revised. Their respective type species, L.
   bigutta Walker, 1854 and P. irrorata Hampson, 1900 are redescribed. A
   total of 10 and 20 Lysceia and Pasteosia species placed in three and
   five informally named species groups, respectively, are described as
   new: Lysceia flava spec. nov. (flava group), L. bonaespei spec. nov., L.
   geertsemai spec. nov., L. cohabitans spec. nov., L. knysnaensis spec.
   nov., L. imitans spec. nov., L. kubusensis spec. nov., L. bistagma spec.
   nov., L. obscurata spec. nov. (bonaespei group); L. montivaga spec. nov.
   (montivaga group); and Pasteosia murina spec. nov., P. poliographa spec.
   nov., P. cinerea spec. nov., P spodoptera spec. nov., P minor spec. nov.
   (murina group), P. tephrinata spec. nov., P. petrodes spec.-nov., P.
   intermedia spec. nov., P. furva spec. nov., P lightfooti spec. nov.
   (tephrinata group); P. pallens spec. nov. (pallens group), P. nivalis
   spec. nov., P. swartbergensis spec. nov., P. promontorii spec. nov., P.
   angulata spec. nov., P aerumnosa spec. nov., P aurora spec. nov., P
   favifiacea spec. nov. (nivalis group); and P inornata spec. nov. and P
   mendax spec. nov. (montivaga group). The two type species are placed in
   monotypic species groups of their own. The biogeography of the two
   putative sister genera is briefly characterized; both reach their
   greatest diversity in the former Cape Province of South Africa,
   especially the present Western Cape. Keys to the genera and to species
   within Lysceia Walker and Pasteosia Hampson are provided, as are
   illustrations of adults and genitalia and distribution maps. The
   revision is complemented by a gazetteer.
C1 Kruger, M.; Ditsong Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB 413, Pretoria, ZA-0001,
   South Africa, South Africa.
EM kruger@ditsong.org.za

   Lysceia kubusensis (Arctiidae): [Sp nov, South Africa, P. 24]. 
   Lysceia montivaga (Arctiidae): [Sp nov, Zimbabwe, P. 29]. 
   Lysceia obscurata (Arctiidae): [Sp nov, South Africa, P. 27].

DT Article
TI Celsumaria: a new genus of Grapholitini from the Afrotropical Region
   (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae).
AU Brown, John W.
   Timm, Alicia E.
SO Annals of the Ditsong National Museum of Natural History
VL 7
PS 97-108
PD May 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Celsumaria gen. nov., is described to accommodate C. grandis spec. nov.
   from South Africa; C. knysna spec. nov. (type species) from South
   Africa; C. elongate spec. nov. from Madagascar; C. soror spec. nov. from
   Madagascar; and C. hygrantis (Meyrick) comb. nov., from the Seychelles.
   Species of Celsumaria are extremely similar in facies and genitalia, but
   they can be circumscribed by a combination of subtle differences in male
   genitalia and male secondary scaling on the hindwing coupled with DNA
   barcodes. The new genus shares a somewhat 'inflated' valva with species
   of Cryptophlebia Walsingham, 1900 and Thaumatotibia Zacher, 1915. The
   possession of an unusual orbicular, sclerotized process in the middle of
   the valva in the male genitalia strongly suggests a close relationship
   with Dracontogena Diakonoff, 1970. The monophyly of Celsumaria is
   supported by the raised, curled scales on the forewing in both sexes.
C1 Brown, John W.; Natl Museum Nat Hist, Dept Entomol, Washington, DC,
   20013, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

AN ZOOR15404023332
DT Article
TI Transfer of three species of Namakwanus Scholtz & Howden to Versicorpus
   Deschodt, Davis & Scholtz or to Namaphilus gen. nov., with descriptions
   of two new species (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Scarabaeinae).
AU Deschodt, Christian M. (cdeschodt@zoology.up.ac.za) 
   Davis, Adrian L.V.
SO Annals of the Ditsong National Museum of Natural History
VL 7
PS 109-114
PD May 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Taxonomic changes are made in the Byrrhidium group of Canthonini dung
   beetles. The genera Versicorpus Deschodt, Davis & Scholtz, 2011 and
   Namakwanus Scholtz & Howden, 1987 currently comprise one and four
   species, respectively. Re-examination of the type material of Namakwanus
   irishi Scholtz & Howden, 1987 indicates that the holotype and paratypes
   from mountains near Windhoek, Namibia, differ from the paratype from the
   Kuiseb River near Gobabeb in the Central Namib, warranting description
   of a new species, Namakwanus scholtzi spec. nov. Other species included
   in the genus, Namakwanus davisi Deschodt & Scholtz, 2007 and Namakwanus
   endroedyi Deschodt, Davis & Scholtz, 2011, differ sufficiently to
   warrant removal to a new genus, Namaphilus gen. nov. A further new
   species, Namaphilus ameibensis spec. nov., is added to the new genus.
   Namakwanus streyi Frolov, 2005 is transferred to Versicorpus. Lastly a
   new, updated key and some notes on all the known Byrrhidium group
   species are provided.
C1 Deschodt, Christian M.; Univ Pretoria, Dept Zool & Entomol, Pretoria,
   South Africa, South Africa.
